context: A number of theories have been proposed regarding Avicenna's <b5_0>madhab<b5_0/> (school of thought within Islamic jurisprudence). <a1_0><b11_0>Medieval historian Ẓahīr al-dīn al-Bayhaqī<b11_0/><a1_0/> (d. 1169) considered <b7_0>Avicenna<b7_0/> to be a follower of <a0_0><b10_0>the <b6_0>Brethren of Purity<b10_0/><b6_0/><a0_0/>. On the other hand, Dimitri Gutas along with Aisha Khan and <a4_0><b14_0>Jules J. Janssens<b14_0/><a4_0/> demonstrated that Avicenna was a <a2_0><b12_0>Sunni<a2_0/> Hanafi<b12_0/>.
